child.pub-comments: "Moving further south, the languages of Middle Ramu, such as Rao, also seem to be members of the family, although their exact position remains to be worked out. […] At this point, pending further investigation, I will assign these Middle Ramu languages to the family as a first order subgroup" (Foley 2005:125).

child.pub-comments: "A number of exclusively shared lexical items suggest that Adjora is a member of the Lower Ramu sub-family…and the evidence points the same way for Banaro" (Foley 2005:125-26).

child.publications: Foley, William A. 2005. Linguistic prehistory in the Sepik-Ramu basin. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858835622
child.pub-comments: "Turning to the west, the languages of the grass country, such as Adjora and Banaro, are also clearly Lower Sepik-Ramu" (Foley 2005:125).

child.pub-comments: "The WAG languages are by far the best known, having been the focus of my own intensive fieldwork" (Foley 2005:116).

child.pub-comments: "To the south of the Tangu languages, the close grouping of seven languages, called by Laycock and Z'graggen (1975:740) the Tamolan family, appears to belong to it [the Lower Sepik-Ramu family], indeed to the Lower Ramu branch of it" (Foley 2005:125).

child.pub-comments: "This sub-family is larger, more diversified, and less well known than the Lower Sepik family" (Foley 2005:112).

child.pub-comments: "Kambot is most probably a member of the Lower Sepik-Ramu family. […] While the slender evidence does indicate that Kambot is a member of the family, it has no close relatives within it, and represents another first order subgroup" (Foley 2005:126).

child.pub-comments: "The grouping of Yimas with Karawari and Kopar with Murik is well established and unquestionable (Foley 1986, 1991)..." (Foley 2005:111)

root.geography: spoken in the Sepik-Ramu river basins
root.pub-comments: "While I demonstrate that the evidence for their genetic link is irrefutable, the languages of the two sub-families, Lower Sepik and Lower Ramu, are structurally and lexically very different" (Foley 2005:110).
